body.p: Action potentials pass from atria to ventricles through the __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. This node is found at the superior edge of the atria. The AV node is the connection between the atria and ventricles.
Incorrect. The internodal conducting pathway is contained within the atria and does not connect the atria to the ventricles. The AV node is the connection between the atria and ventricles.
Correct. AV stands for atrioventricular, indicating it is the connection between the two.
Incorrect. These fibers carry the action potentials through the ventricles. The AV node is the connection between the atria and ventricles.

body.p: Which part of the heart’s conduction system is known as the “pacemaker”?

feedback.p: Correct. The SA node depolarizes spontaneously and it creates the signal for contraction.
Incorrect. The AV node can take over if the SA node becomes dysfunctional but it is not the primary pacemaker of the heart.
Incorrect. The purkinje fibers carry the signal but they do not initiate it.
Incorrect. The Bundles of His carry the signal but they do not initiate it.

body.p: The heart exhibits automaticity which means:

input.choice: It is controlled by the autonomic nervous system.
It is controlled by the somatic nervous system.
It sets the pace of its beat.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although the autonomic nervous system can influence the frequency of beats, it is not required for the heart to beat.
Correct. Automaticity means the heart can generate its own beat by having cells that spontaneously depolarize.
Incorrect. The heart is influenced by the autonomic nervous system not the somatic.
Incorrect. Being able to create its own beat is automaticity. Being able to set its own pace is rhythmicity.

body.p: The effects of increased parasympathetic nervous system activity include __________.

input.choice: slowing the rate of conduction through the AV node only
decreasing heart rate and slowing the rate of conduction through the AV node

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although this is one of its effects, it is not its only effect. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates both the SA and AV nodes and therefore has effects on both.
Incorrect. The parasympathetic nervous system does not slow heart rate. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates both the SA and AV nodes and therefore has effects on both.
Incorrect. Although this is one of its effects, it is not the only effect. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates both the SA and AV nodes and therefore has effects on both.
Correct. The parasympathetic nervous system innervates both the SA and AV nodes and therefore has effects on both.

body.p: Which of the following is NOT correctly paired?

feedback.p: Correct. The p wave represents atrial depolarization.
Incorrect. This is a correct pair. The p wave represents atrial depolarization.
Incorrect. This is a correct pair. The p wave represents atrial depolarization.

body.p: Increased parasympathetic activity to the AV node would most likely result in __________.

input.choice: an increase in the duration of the P wave
a decrease in the duration of the P wave
an increase in the duration of the P-R interval
an increase in the S-T interval

feedback.p: Incorrect. Changes at the AV node do not affect atrial depolarization. Parasympathetic activity will decrease the conduction rate of the AV node, thus lengthening the P-R interval.
Incorrect. Changes at the AV node do not affect atrial depolarization. Parasympathetic activity will decrease the conduction rate of the AV node, thus lengthening the P-R interval.
Correct. The P-R interval includes the time it takes for conduction to occur through the AV node. Parasympathetic activity will decrease this conduction rate, lengthening the interval.

Incorrect. The S-T interval represents the time of ventricular action potentials, which are not affected by innervation to the AV node. Parasympathetic activity will decrease the conduction rate of the AV node, thus lengthening the P-R interval.

body.p: The first heart sound is associated with which mechanical event?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although there is sometimes a third heart sound associated with rapid filling after the opening of the AV valve, it does not cause the first heart sound. The first heart sound is created as the AV valves “snap” shut.
Correct. The first heart sound is created as the AV valves “snap” shut.
Incorrect. The heart sounds are associated with valves closing. The first heart sound is created as the AV valves “snap” shut.
Incorrect. Although this does create a heart sound, it is the second sound and not the first. The first heart sound is created as the AV valves “snap” shut.

body.p: In people with atrial fibrillation, the atria do not contract properly. To what extent would this affect ventricular filling?

input.choice: There would be no change in ventricular filling.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although ventricular filling might be affected, most individuals are fine at rest with atrial fibrillation.
Correct. About 10-20% of the filling volume is due to atrial systole. Because the atria do not contract in a coordinated manner during fibrillation, some or all of this filling will be lost.
Incorrect. Because atrial systole helps push blood into the ventricles, a change would be likely to occur.
Incorrect. However, ventricular filling is unlikely to increase with dysfunction of the atria.

body.p: During exercise, a person’s cardiac output (CO) might rise to 15 Liters/min. If their heart rate (HR) is 150 beats per minute during this time, what would their stroke volume (SV) be?

feedback.p: Incorrect. 80 mL/beat x 150 beats/min = 12000 ml/min = 12 L/min. Given the values for cardiac output (CO) and heart rate (HR), the stroke volume (SV) is 100 mL/beat.
Correct. 100 mL/beat x 150 beats/min = 15000 ml/min = 12 L/min.

Incorrect. Although this may be a reasonable value in a strenuously exercising individual, it is not the correct answer in this scenario. Given the values for cardiac output (CO) and heart rate (HR), the stroke volume (SV) is 100 mL/beat.

body.p: Cardiac output is the blood flow to the whole body. What is/are the most important determinant(s) of cardiac output?

input.choice: the needs of the organs of the body

feedback.p: Correct. The cardiac output represents the total needs of the organs of the body.
Incorrect. Although HR and SV can be used to determine cardiac output, these variables are adjusted by the body to meet organ needs.

Incorrect. Although cardiac output can be determined by dividing blood pressure by vascular resistance, they are not the most important determinants of cardiac output. The total needs of the organs of the body determine cardiac output.

body.p: What equipment is necessary to measure blood pressure by the auscultatory (examination by listening) method?

input.choice: pulse oximeter and blood pressure cuff
pulse oximeter, stethoscope and blood pressure cuff

feedback.p: Incorrect. Only one of these two instruments is necessary. A stethoscope is used to amplify the faint sound while the blood pressure cuff is used to modulate the size of the arterial lumen and display the pressures.

Incorrect. Only one of these two instruments is necessary. A stethoscope is used to amplify the faint sound while the blood pressure cuff is used to modulate the size of the arterial lumen and display the pressures.
Incorrect. Only two of these is necessary. A stethoscope is used to amplify the faint sound while the blood pressure cuff is used to modulate the size of the arterial lumen and display the pressures.
Correct. The stethoscope is used to amplify the faint sound while the blood pressure cuff is used to modulate the size of the arterial lumen and display the pressures.

body.p: If a person has a blood pressure measurement of 130/100, what is the approximate mean arterial pressure (MAP)?

feedback.p: Incorrect. This would be the average of the diastolic and systolic value, but because the heart spends more time in diastole than systole, this is not a good approximation over time. Mean arterial pressure is approximated as diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures; therefore, the MAP is 110 mmHg.
Correct. Mean arterial pressure is approximated as diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures.

Incorrect. This is the diastolic pressure. Mean arterial pressure is approximated as diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures; therefore, the MAP is 110 mmHg.

Incorrect. This is the systolic pressure. Mean arterial pressure is approximated as diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures; therefore, the MAP is 110 mmHg.

body.p: What is the relationship between pressure, flow and resistance?

input.choice: change in pressure = flow x resistance
flow = change in pressure x resistance
resistance = change in pressure x flow

feedback.p: Correct. A pressure drop occurs because of the combination of flow and resistance.
Incorrect. Although flow can be calculated if pressure and resistance are known, it is not calculated by multiplying these variables.
Incorrect. Although resistance can be calculated if flow and pressure are known, it is not calculated by multiplying these variables.

body.p: One of the determinants of blood pressure is cardiac output. Which of the following most directly determine cardiac output?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although heart rate is one of the determinants, viscosity is not a direct determinant of cardiac output.
Correct. Cardiac output is determined by multiplying strove volume and heart rate.
Incorrect. Both of these variables contribute to the resistance of a vessel, but do not directly determine cardiac output.
Incorrect. Although stroke volume is one of the direct determinants of cardiac output, vascular diameter does not. Instead it is a major determinant of vascular resistance.

body.p: One of the determinants of blood pressure is vascular resistance. Which of the following lists each of the factors that most directly determine vascular resistance?

input.choice: viscosity, vessel diameter, and vessel length
viscosity, vessel diameter, vessel length, and flow through the vessel
viscosity, vessel diameter, vessel length, and hematocrit

feedback.p: Correct. Each of these factors affect vascular resistance.
Incorrect. Although viscosity, vessel diameter, vessel length are correct, flow is independent of resistance.
Incorrect. Although both of these contribute to vascular resistance, they do not represent a comprehensive list. Viscosity must also be included as a factor directly affecting vascular resistance.
Incorrect. Viscosity, vessel diameter, and vessel length are factors that most directly affect vascular resistance. Hematocrit determines blood viscosity.

body.p: What is the main function of capillaries?

input.choice: Provide a place for exchange of oxygen, nutrients and waste products.

feedback.p: Correct. Capillaries are necessary for maintaining tissues.
Incorrect. This is the main function of arteries. Capillaries are necessary for maintaining tissues.
Incorrect. This is the job of lymphatic capillaries. Capillaries are necessary for maintaining tissues.

body.p: Hydrostatic pressure is another name for __________.

feedback.p: Correct. The blood pressure in any point in a vessel is the same as its hydrostatic pressure. Note that this is different from how the term blood pressure is commonly used in clinical medicine. In that case the term is used in reference to the pressure in the large arteries.
Incorrect. Atmospheric pressure represents the weight of the atmosphere, not a fluid pressure in the body. The blood pressure in any point in a vessel is the same as its hydrostatic pressure.

Incorrect. Osmotic pressure is not the best choice. Although osmotic pressure can be viewed as the hydrostatic pressure required to oppose osmosis. The blood pressure in any point in a vessel is the same as its hydrostatic pressure.

body.p: The requirements for osmotic pressure include __________.

input.choice: a pressure generating chamber (such as the heart) and a semi-permeable membrane
dissolved solutes and a semi-permeable membrane
pressure generating chamber and dissolved solutes

feedback.p: Incorrect. The heart is necessary for generating hydrostatic pressure in the body, but not osmotic pressure. An osmotic pressure difference is generated when differing concentrations of dissolved solutes are separated by a membrane that does not allow the solutes to cross, but does allow water to cross.

Correct. An osmotic pressure difference is generated when differing concentrations of dissolved solutes are separated by a membrane that does not allow the solutes to cross, but does allow water to cross.

Incorrect. Only one of these contributes to osmotic pressure. An osmotic pressure difference is generated when differing concentrations of dissolved solutes are separated by a membrane that does not allow the solutes to cross, but does allow water to cross.

body.p: Starling’s Law of capillaries can be used to __________.

input.choice: determine the flow through a capillary
predict tissue capillary density based on metabolic measurements
determine the diameter to length ratio of a capillary

feedback.p: Incorrect. Flow through a capillary can be calculated by dividing the pressure drop across the capillary by resistance of the capillary. This is not Starling’s law. Starling’s law of capillaries is used to calculate the net filtration pressure.
Correct. The net filtration pressure, in turn, determines the flow rate across the capillary wall.

Incorrect. Although capillary density is often associated with the metabolic demands of a tissue, this is not related to Starling’s law. Starling’s law of capillaries is used to calculate the net filtration pressure.
Incorrect. Starling’s law relates to pressures, not lengths. Starling’s law of capillaries is used to calculate the net filtration pressure.

input.choice: excess fluid accumulation in the capillaries
excess fluid accumulation in the interstitial space

feedback.p: Incorrect. Excess fluid accumulation in the capillaries might lead to edema; however, edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial space of tissue.
Incorrect. Congestion of blood vessels is not edema unless it transfers to surrounding tissues. Edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial space of tissue.
Correct. Edema causes tissues to swell because the interstitial space is expanded.
Incorrect. Although congestion in the heart can lead to edema, it is not edema itself. Edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the interstitial space of tissue.

body.p: Select all of the following that would negatively affect venous return.

feedback.p: Correct. When right atrial pressure is increased, it is harder for blood to flow into the right heart. When standing, the blood moving back to the heart has to overcome the effects of gravity. This is not the case when lying down.

Half correct. When right atrial pressure is increased, it is harder for blood to flow into the right heart. Standing also negatively affects venous return. When standing, the blood moving back to the heart has to overcome the effects of gravity. This is not the case when lying down.

Half correct. When standing, the blood moving back to the heart has to overcome the effects of gravity. This is not the case when lying down. Increased right atrial pressure also negatively affects venous return. When right atrial pressure is increased, it is harder for blood to flow into the right heart.

Incorrect. Walking stimulates venous return by using the skeletal muscle pump. Hypertension should not be selected because arterial pressures are not necessarily a good indicator of venous return. The pressures in the venules compared to the pressure in the right atrium determine how large the pressure gradient is to drive venous return. Increased right atrial pressure is a correct answer because when right atrial pressure is increased, it is harder for blood to flow into the right heart. Standing should also be selected as a correct answer. When standing, the blood moving back to the heart has to overcome the effects of gravity. This is not the case when lying down.

body.p: How does the skeletal muscle pump increase venous return?

input.choice: by increasing colloid osmotic pressure, which pulls blood toward the heart
by decreasing hydrostatic pressure in the right atrium
by increasing hydrostatic pressure in veins
by decreasing hydrostatic pressure in the veins

feedback.p: Incorrect. These processes have no effect on colloid osmotic pressure, which is a pressure important in regulating fluid movement across capillaries, not along blood vessels.
Incorrect. Although they both affect hydrostatic pressure, it is not a decrease, nor in the right atrium.
Correct. By increasing hydrostatic pressure in the veins, there is a larger pressure gradient to move blood toward the right atrium.
Incorrect. Decreasing hydrostatic pressure in the veins would lead to a smaller pressure gradient for returning blood to the heart.

body.p: How does the velocity of flow (units are cm/sec) compare in the aorta versus the capillaries?

input.choice: It is slower in the aorta.
It is faster in the aorta.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Velocity varies significantly through the vascular system.

Incorrect. Velocity is determined by dividing the cross sectional area of a vessel, or the combination of vessels (in cm) by the flow rate through the vessel order. The flow rate through the vascular system is the same everywhere (for example, 5 liters/min), but the total cross sectional area is much larger in the capillaries than it is in the aorta, allowing blood to flow at a lower velocity in the capillaries. Velocity can be calculated by dividing the flow rate by the total cross-sectional area of the vessel order. The aorta has a cross sectional area of 2.5 cm2 while the capillaries have a cross-sectional area of 2500 cm2.

Correct. The flow rate through the vascular system is the same everywhere (for example, 5 liters/min), but the total cross sectional area is much larger in the capillaries than it is in the aorta, allowing blood to flow at a lower velocity in the capillaries. Velocity can be calculated by dividing the flow rate by the total cross-sectional area of the vessel order. The aorta has a cross sectional area of 2.5 cm2 while the capillaries have a cross-sectional area of 2500 cm2.

body.p: The brachiocephalic vein carries blood returning to the heart from the __________.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Blood returns from the legs via the femoral and other veins. The brachiocephalic vein returns blood from the arms and head to the hearts.
Incorrect. Blood returns from these organs vie the renal and hepatic veins, respectively. The brachiocephalic vein returns blood from the arms and head to the hearts.
Incorrect. Although the brachiocephalic vein does carry blood from the head, it does not do so from the stomach. The brachiocephalic vein returns blood from the arms and head to the hearts.
Correct. Brachi- refers to arm and cephalic means “toward the head.”

body.p: Right ventricular systolic pressure is less than left ventricular systolic pressure because __________.

input.choice: the right ventricle pumps less blood
the right ventricle pumps into a lower resistance
the right ventricle is more muscular, allowing it to pump more blood at lower tension

feedback.p: Incorrect. Both ventricles pump the same amount of blood. The pulmonary circulation has about 1/5 the resistance of the systemic circulation.
Correct. The pulmonary circulation has about 1/5 the resistance of the systemic circulation
Incorrect. The left ventricle is more muscular. The pulmonary circulation has about 1/5 the resistance of the systemic circulation.
